translations.intro3: Spanish Mirrors is the 1st book of its kind: one of 10 mirroring legends that place Salvadoran and Spanish legends side by side, revealing how distant cultures reflect the same symbols and fears.
translations.author1: is a Spanish‚ÄìSalvadoran technology strategist, traveler, and cultural storyteller dedicated to changing how the world sees El Salvador ‚Äî through the timeless power of folklore.
translations.author2: Although his professional background began in IT, Federico‚Äôs path as a writer emerged while living as an immigrant in Poland, Spain, and Luxembourg, and traveling across more than twenty countries. In conversations abroad, he repeatedly encountered simplified or distorted views of his homeland. Yet when he shared Salvadoran legends‚Äîstories shaped by memory, fear, morality, and imagination‚Äîpeople were often surprised by their depth and universality. Many asked where they could learn more. None spoke Spanish, and there was nothing he could recommend.
translations.author3: That recurring gap led him to create the first series of Salvadoran folklore books written directly in English, designed for international readers while remaining faithful to oral tradition. What began as cultural preservation soon evolved into something broader.
translations.author31: With Spanish Mirrors, Federico introduced a new approach. Rather than presenting folklore as isolated national curiosities, the book places Salvadoran and Spanish legends in direct dialogue. Each section pairs two figures‚Äîdevils, guardians, tricksters, heralds of death, restless spirits‚Äîand follows them with a comparative reflection examining their shared archetypes, moral functions, and symbolic boundaries. Across cultures separated by an ocean, the same questions emerge: how societies explain evil, enforce limits, warn the living, and give form to the unknown.
translations.author311: While the series has become a cultural bridge for the Salvadoran diaspora and their descendants, Federico‚Äôs broader aim has always been universal: to show that folklore is not about the past alone, but about how humans everywhere confront fear, responsibility, temptation, and fate.
translations.author32: Since their release, these stories have been featured at international book fairs and presented at embassies, Instituto Cervantes, and cultural events across the globe ‚Äî from the U.S. and China to Australia.
translations.author4: He often says: ‚ÄúThe only person who can reshape your destiny is the one you see in the mirror.‚Äù Through these stories, he invites readers to see not just El Salvador ‚Äî but themselves ‚Äî in a whole new light.
